intro: Oxytropis jacquinii, commonly known as the Jacquin's locoweed, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Mexico. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, also known as the legume or pea family, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. It is known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock. Oxytropis jacquinii plays a role in its ecosystem by providing forage for certain wildlife and contributing to soil stabilization.
